prompt.p: A 42-year-old woman presents complaining of weight gain, visual loss and change in menstrual cycle. On examination there is hair loss (male-pattern baldness), and skin pigmentation and bruising. There is truncal obesity and proximal muscle atrophy. Her blood pressure is 141/85 mmHg. Investigations show:
Fasting blood glucose 7.0 mmol/L(normal range 3.6–5.8 mmol/L)
What is the most likely anatomical location of a lesion causing the patient's symptoms and signs?

modalFeedback.p: Option D is Correct. This patient has symptoms and signs of cortisol excess. Moreover, there is skin pigmentation due to a pituitary corticotroph adenoma releasing melanocyte stimulating hormone. This would not occur with an adrenal cortex (zona fasciculata) adenoma.
Option A is Incorrect. Excess cortisol from the cortex would produce the symptoms and signs described except for the visual changes due to pituitary adenoma compression of the optic chiasma.
Option B is Incorrect. Produces catecholamines. These do not produce the symptoms and signs described.
Option C is Incorrect. Oestrogen is the sex hormone produced by the ovary and would not cause the symptoms described.
Option E is Incorrect. Thyroxine and triiodothyronine produced by the thyroid would not produce the symptoms and signs described
